prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not wanting to do my daughters hair every day
My daughter is 2. She has thick ringlets like I do. My hair routine takes a minimum of an hour a day to get my hair looking presentable, and it takes a lot of work.

My partner repeatedly requests that I do the same hair care routine for our daughter so that she knows how to care for her hair when she’s older. I do some of it, like washing with the right products, brushing, and putting in leave in products, but she’s also 2. It doesn’t make sense to me to put hours of effort into her hair when she’s just going to run around and ruin it. On top of that, her baby mop top is cute and I don’t want her to feel like she needs to dedicate so much time to her hair to feel beautiful.

My partner however is insistent that I do her hair and complains constantly when I don’t, even when I explain all of the time and effort and money that goes into it. My partner emphasizes that they want our daughter to look “presentable”, but I disagree. AITA for refusing?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is at fault (AITA) for not wanting to do their daughter's hair every day. The daughter is 2 years old, and the author has a complex hair routine that takes an hour. The partner wants the daughter to learn the routine now for when she's older.

First, the author argues that it's impractical for a 2-year-old to need such a routine daily. Kids at that age are active, so meticulous styling would be ruined quickly. Plus, the author wants the daughter to feel that her natural hair is beautiful without needing hours of maintenance. The partner, on the other hand, insists on "presentable" looks, which might be more about their own preferences or societal expectations.

The key points are the age of the child, the practicality of the routine, and the parent's differing views on beauty standards. The author is balancing practicality with the child's well-being versus the partner's expectations. Since the daughter is very young, enforcing a strict adult hair routine might not be necessary. Also, the author's concern about not making the child feel she needs to spend a lot of time on hair to be beautiful is valid. The partner's insistence seems to be causing conflict without a strong justification for a toddler. So, the author isn't in the wrong here. They're making a reasonable choice based on the child's age and their own values.
